statement.text: Carotid coiling and kinking are elongation abnormalities of the internal carotid artery that may rarely cause hemodynamically significant stenosis with neck movement, sometimes warranting surgical correction when symptomatic.

explanation.intuition: The carotid artery can become excessively long and twisted over time, like a garden hose that's been coiled up. Usually this causes no problem, but in rare cases the kinks can crimp blood flow with certain head positions.
explanation.key_insight: Most carotid coiling/kinking is asymptomatic and found incidentally. Symptomatic cases require exclusion of other causes of TIA/stroke before attributing symptoms to the kink. Dynamic angiography with head movement may reveal positional stenosis.
explanation.technical_details: Classification: tortuosity (mild), coiling (complete loop), kinking (acute angle). Etiology: congenital elongation, atherosclerosis, hypertension, aging. Incidence: 10-25% of population (mostly asymptomatic). Symptoms: rare, positional TIA/stroke symptoms. Diagnosis: duplex with head rotation, dynamic angiography. Treatment: surgical shortening or resection if definitively symptomatic after excluding other causes.

clinical_features.symptoms: Rare positional TIA/stroke symptoms with head movement
clinical_features.diagnosis: Duplex with head rotation, dynamic CTA/angiography

clinical_pearls: Most carotid coiling/kinking is incidental and asymptomatic
Exclude other causes before attributing symptoms to kink
Dynamic angiography with head movement may reveal positional stenosis
